resources.string: SU permission denied or not available! If you don\'t have root, press \'Root workaround\' to get instructions on how to enable no-root mode
The lockscreen timeout value on your device is too high!

Some devices have Doze mode disabled by the OEM. This option can enable Doze mode on devices which do not have it enabled by default.\n\nNote: You need to turn on the ForceDoze module in Xposed and enable \'Enable Doze on unsupported device\' option in the app\'s Settings, in order to permanently enable Doze. If you don\'t have Xposed installed, you will have to turn this option on every time you restart your phone.

"ForceDoze has detected that Xposed is installed on your device. In order to make Doze permanently enabled on your device, you need to turn on the ForceDoze module in Xposed and enable 'Enable Doze on unsupported device' option in the app's Settings. If you don't turn on the module, you will lose Doze functionality on device restart and will have to manually enable Doze again. "

If your device isn't rooted, you can manually grant the permission 'android.permission.DUMP' to this app by executing the following ADB command from your PC (the command is one-line, not separated):

 "adb -d shell pm grant com.suyashsrijan.forcedoze android.permission.DUMP"

 Once you have done, please close this app and start again and you will then be able to access the app properly.
The lockscreen timeout value on your device is too high (
" mins). This means your device does not "
"automatically lock itself after the screen turns off until "
" mins have passed. This also means ForceDoze will wait "

" mins before making your device enter Doze mode by using a temporary wake lock. If you want ForceDoze to make the device enter Doze mode faster, consider reducing the lockscreen timeout to Immediately in your device's Security Settings. If you want ForceDoze to make the device enter Doze mode regardless of the lockscreen timeout, turn on 'Ignore lockscreen timeout' option in ForceDoze Settings."

How Doze mode works on your device:

If a user leaves a device unplugged and stationary for a period of time (30 mins), with the screen off, the device enters Doze mode. In Doze mode, the system attempts to conserve battery by restricting apps' access to network and CPU-intensive services. It also prevents apps from accessing the network and defers their jobs, syncs, and standard alarms

Periodically, the system exits Doze for a brief time to let apps complete their deferred activities. During this maintenance window, the system runs all pending syncs, jobs, and alarms, and lets apps access the network

At the conclusion of each maintenance window, the system again enters Doze, suspending network access and deferring jobs, syncs, and alarms. Over time, the system schedules maintenance windows less and less frequently, helping to reduce battery consumption in cases of longer-term inactivity when the device is not connected to a charger.

As soon as the user wakes the device by moving it, turning on the screen, or connecting a charger, the system exits Doze and all apps return to normal activity

How ForceDoze works:

ForceDoze makes the device enter Doze mode immediately after screen off (or after a user specified delay), instead of waiting for 30 mins for the device to become stationary. On top of that, ForceDoze also turns of the device's motion sensors, so Doze doesn't deactivate if you move your device. Doze will only deactivate during a maintenance window (as explained above) or when you turn on your screen, which means your device will stay in Doze mode for a much longer time even if the device's screen is off and the device is not stationary, which means the battery savings will be a lot higher than normal Doze.
SU permission denied or SU not available, so cannot read logcat

"An app that is whitelisted can use the network and hold partial wake locks during Doze and App Standby. However, other restrictions still apply to the whitelisted app, just as they do to other apps. For example, the whitelisted appâ€™s jobs and syncs are deferred, and its regular AlarmManager alarms do not fire. "
The app you\'re trying to add is already whitelisted!
The app you\'re trying to remove does not exist in the whitelist

ForceDoze enables Doze the moment you turn off your screen. It also disables motion sensing so Doze doesn\'t accidentally deactivate unless it\'s time to execute maintenance jobs, making battery savings much higher than standard Doze functionality
Don\'t disable sensors on screen off
Don\'t disable device sensors when the device goes into Doze mode
Turn off ForceDoze when device is plugged in to a charger
Workaround for auto-rotate and auto-brightness not working after screen on
Show Doze stats in persistent notification
Ignore lockscreen timeout and enable Doze immediately after screen off
Add a delay before Doze mode kicks in after screen-off
Enables Doze on an unsupported device
Prevent Doze from accessing motion sensors (experimental)
Reset ForceDoze to the default state
ForceDoze is now enabled and your standby battery life is going to be much more improved!

ForceDoze is a completely free and open-source app with no ads and I\'ve put a lot of time into making and improving it, with weekly updates to fix bugs and add/improve features. If you like my work, please consider donating in order to motivate me to work harder and produce even more useful apps!
ForceDoze for Android is built using open source software:

Thanks to the following people for translating ForceDoze into other languages: 

Spanish: monza1412 (XDA)
Portuguese-BR: GamerVicioX (GitHub)
SU permission denied or not available!
ForceDoze requires permission to modify the auto-rotate and auto-brightness setting on your phone in order to use this feature. Press \'Authorize\' to grant permission, or press \'Cancel\' to deny
Doze battery stats was successfully cleared!

ForceDoze has resetted itself. The following changes were made: 

1) Stop ForceDoze service
2) Re-enable sensors, just in case they are disabled
3) Disable and re-enable Doze mode, to ensure Doze mode is turned on properly
4) Reset app preferences
5) Revoke DUMP and READ_LOGS (if granted) permission

It is recommended that you restart your device. The app will restart now!

Doze Delay value is currently too high and may have a negative effect on battery life. Make sure to test the effects of the delay on battery life and consider reducing the delay if there is a noticeable drop in battery life.

Resetting ForceDoze will make the following changes: 

1) Stop ForceDoze service
2) Re-enable sensors, just in case they are disabled
3) Disable and re-enable Doze mode, to ensure Doze mode is turned on properly
4) Reset app preferences
5) Revoke DUMP and READ_LOGS (if granted) permission

Do you want to continue?
Disables WiFi/mobile data during Doze (doesn\'t affect Doze maintenance windows)
